article.title: The chemistry of episodic accretion in embedded objects. 2D radiation thermo-chemical models of the post-burst phase

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the density and temperature structure for a representative Class I model. What causes the lower temperatures in the envelope structure close to the midplane, as compared to a simple 1D spherical model?
choices: The presence of an outflow cavity.
The impact of interstellar FUV radiation.
The disk absorbing most of the stellar radiation and casting a shadow.
The use of two different dust populations for the disk and envelope.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the dust opacities for the envelope and disk dust populations. Which statement about the dust opacities is true?
choices: The dust opacity is identical for both the envelope and disk.
The dust opacity is higher for the disk at all wavelengths.
The dust opacity is higher for the envelope at wavelengths shorter than 10 Âµm.
The dust opacity is dominated by scattering at all wavelengths.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the evolution of the CO gas phase abundance in the post-burst phase. What causes the depletion of CO in the outer regions of the structure (r > 300 au) after the burst?
choices: Photodissociation by the interstellar radiation field.
Conversion of CO to CO2 due to efficient chemical reactions.
Freeze-out of CO due to the decrease in temperature.
Outflow removing CO from the outer regions of the structure.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows C18O J=2-1 ALMA simulations for the representative Class I model in a face-on view. What causes the dark gap in the intensity map that appears around 1000 years after the burst?
choices: CO being removed by a strong outflow.
CO being photodissociated by the strong radiation field.
CO freezing out in the inner regions due to lower temperatures.
CO being converted to other molecules by chemical reactions.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure compares the measured C18O J=2-1 extent with the current bolometric luminosity for models with and without bursts. What does this figure indicate about the detectability of bursts using CO observations?
choices: Strong bursts are easily detectable for a long time after the burst, whereas weak bursts are hard to detect.
Only very strong bursts can be detected using CO observations.
CO observations are not a suitable method to identify post-burst objects.
Bursts are only detectable during the burst itself, not in the post-burst phase.
